# History of Las Vegas

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This article **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). This **history of Las Vegas** covers both the city of [Las
Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas,_Nevada "Las Vegas, Nevada"), [Nevada](/wiki/Nevada
"Nevada"), and the [Las Vegas Valley](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Valley "Las Vegas
Valley").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/20/Southern_Paiutes.jpg)](/wiki/File:Southern_Paiutes.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Southern_Paiutes.jpg "Enlarge")

Southern [Paiutes](/wiki/Paiutes "Paiutes") at
[Moapa](/wiki/Moapa_River_Indian_Reservation "Moapa River Indian Reservation")
wearing traditional Paiute cradleboard and rabbit robe

The name Las Vegas was given to the area in 1821 by Rafael Rivera, a member of
the [Antonio Armijo](/wiki/Antonio_Armijo "Antonio Armijo") trading party that
was traveling to [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles,_California "Los Angeles,
California"),[1][2][3][4] and stopped for water there on the [Old Spanish
Trail](/wiki/Old_Spanish_Trail_\(trade_route\) "Old Spanish Trail \(trade
route\)") from [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"). At that time,
several parts of the valley contained [artesian wells](/wiki/Artesian_aquifer
"Artesian aquifer") surrounded by extensive green areas; _Las Vegas_ means the
meadows in [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"). The flows
from the wells fed the [Las Vegas Wash](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Wash "Las Vegas
Wash"), which runs to the [Colorado River](/wiki/Colorado_River "Colorado
River").

##
Prehistory[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Prehistory")]

The [prehistoric](/wiki/Prehistoric "Prehistoric") landscape of the [Las Vegas
Valley](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Valley_\(landform\) "Las Vegas Valley \(landform\)")
and most of [Southern Nevada](/wiki/Southern_Nevada "Southern Nevada") was
once a marsh with water and [vegetation](/wiki/Vegetation "Vegetation"). The
rivers that created the marsh eventually went underground, and the marsh
receded. The valley then evolved into a parched, arid landscape that only
supported the hardiest animals and plants.

At some point in the valley's early [geologic history](/wiki/Geology
"Geology"), the water resurfaced and flowed into what is now the Colorado
River. This created a luxurious plant life, forming a [wetland](/wiki/Wetlands
"Wetlands") [oasis](/wiki/Oasis "Oasis") in the [Mojave Desert
landscape](/wiki/Mojave_Desert "Mojave Desert").

Evidence of prehistoric life in Las Vegas Valley was found in 1993, when a
group of construction workers discovered the remains of a [Columbian
mammoth](/wiki/Columbian_mammoth "Columbian mammoth").
[Palaeontologists](/wiki/Palaeontologists "Palaeontologists") estimate that
the mammoth roamed the area some 8,000 to 15,000 years ago.

[Native Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native
Americans in the United States") lived in the Las Vegas Valley, beginning over
10,000 years ago. Archaeologists have discovered baskets,
[petroglyphs](/wiki/Petroglyph "Petroglyph"), [pictographs](/wiki/Pictograph
"Pictograph") and other evidence in diverse locations, including [Gypsum
Cave](/wiki/Gypsum_Cave "Gypsum Cave") and [Tule
Springs](/wiki/Tule_Springs_Archaeological_Site "Tule Springs Archaeological
Site"). [Paiutes](/wiki/Paiute "Paiute") moved into the area as early as AD
700, migrating between nearby mountains in the summer and spending winter in
the valley, near [Big Springs](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Springs "Las Vegas
Springs").[5]

## 1829–1905:
origins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: 1829–1905: origins")]

A trade caravan of 60 men led by the Mexican merchant [Antonio
Armijo](/wiki/Antonio_Armijo "Antonio Armijo") was charged with establishing a
trade route to Los Angeles.[6][7] Las Vegas was named by Mexicans in the
Antonio Armijo party.[8] By following the Pike and Smith routes through a
tributary of Colorado River they came upon the Las Vegas Valley, described by
Smith as the best point to re-supply before going onto California. The
travelers named the area "Las Vegas" which is Spanish for "The Meadows".[9]

[John C. Frémont](/wiki/John_C._Fr%C3%A9mont "John C. Frémont") traveled into
the Las Vegas Valley on May 3, 1844, while it was still part of
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"). He was appointed by President [John
Tyler](/wiki/John_Tyler "John Tyler") to lead a group of
[scientists](/wiki/Scientist "Scientist"), [scouts](/wiki/Reconnaissance
"Reconnaissance"), and [spies](/wiki/Espionage "Espionage") for the [United
States Army Corps of Engineers](/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers
"United States Army Corps of Engineers") who were preparing for a possible war
with Mexico. Upon arriving in the valley they made camp at the [Las Vegas
Springs](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Springs "Las Vegas Springs"), establishing a
clandestine fort there. A [war with Mexico](/wiki/Mexican-American_war
"Mexican-American war") did occur, resulting in the region becoming United
States territory. The fort was used in later years by travellers, [mountain
men](/wiki/Mountain_man "Mountain man"), hunters, and traders seeking shelter,
but was never permanently inhabited.

In 1855, William Bringhurst led a group of 29 Mormon missionaries from Utah to
the Las Vegas Valley. The missionaries built a 150-square-foot (14 m2) adobe
fort near a creek and used flood irrigation to water their crops, a process
still used at the park. However, because of tensions rising between leaders of
the small Mormon community, the summer heat and difficulty growing crops, the
missionaries returned to Utah in 1857, abandoning the fort.

For the next few years the area remained unoccupied by Americans except for
travelers and traders. Then the [U.S. Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United
States Army"), in an attempt to deceive
[Confederate](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America") spies active in southern California in 1864, falsely publicized that
it reclaimed the fort and had renamed it [Fort
Baker](/w/index.php?title=Fort_Baker_\(Nevada\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fort
Baker \(Nevada\) \(page does not exist\)"), briefly recalling the area to
national attention. After the end of the war in 1865, [Octavius
Gass](/wiki/Octavius_Gass "Octavius Gass"), with a commission from the federal
government, re-occupied the fort. The Paiute nation had declined in numbers
and negotiated a new treaty with the United States, ceding the area around the
fort to the United States in return for relocation and supplies of food and
farming equipment. Consequently, Gass started irrigating the old fields and
renamed the area 'Las Vegas Rancho.' Gass made wine at his ranch and Las Vegas
became known as the best stop on the [Old Spanish
Trail](/wiki/Old_Spanish_Trail_\(trade_route\) "Old Spanish Trail \(trade
route\)"). In 1881, because of mismanagement and intrigue with a Mormon
syndicate, Gass lost his ranch to [Archibald
Stewart](/w/index.php?title=Archibald_Stewart_\(American_pioneer\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Archibald Stewart \(American pioneer\) \(page does not exist\)") to pay off a
lien Stewart had on the property.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In
1884, Archibald's wife, [Helen J. Stewart](/wiki/Helen_J._Stewart "Helen J.
Stewart") became the [Las Vegas Postmaster](/wiki/Postmaster "Postmaster").

The property (increased to 1,800 acres (730 ha)), stayed with the family
(despite Archibald Stewart's murder in July 1884) until it was purchased in
1902 by the [San Pedro, Los Angeles, and Salt Lake
Railroad](/wiki/Los_Angeles_and_Salt_Lake_Railroad "Los Angeles and Salt Lake
Railroad"), then being built across southern Nevada. The railroad was a
project of [Montana](/wiki/Montana "Montana")
[Senator](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") [William Andrews
Clark](/wiki/William_Andrews_Clark "William Andrews Clark"). Clark enlisted
Utah's U.S. Senator and mining magnate [Thomas Kearns](/wiki/Thomas_Kearns
"Thomas Kearns") to ensure the line's completion through Utah to Las Vegas.
The State Land Act of 1885 offered land at $1.25 per acre ($3.09/hectare).
Clark and Kearns promoted the area to American farmers who quickly expanded
the farming plots of the areas. Not until 1895 did the first large-scale
migration of Mormons begin in the area, at long last fulfilling Brigham
Young's early dream. Through wells and arid irrigation, agriculture became the
primary industry for the next 20 years and in return for his development, the
farmers named the area Clark County in honor of the railroad tycoon and
Senator.

## 1905–1929: birth, growth and
crisis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1905–1929: birth, growth and crisis")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/StJoanofArcCatholicChurch_in_Las_Vegas_founded_1910.jpg/220px-
StJoanofArcCatholicChurch_in_Las_Vegas_founded_1910.jpg)](/wiki/File:StJoanofArcCatholicChurch_in_Las_Vegas_founded_1910.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:StJoanofArcCatholicChurch_in_Las_Vegas_founded_1910.jpg
"Enlarge")

St. Joan of Arc Catholic Church near 4th and Bridger in downtown was founded
in 1910.[10]

By the early 20th century, water from wells was piped into the town, providing
both a reliable source of fresh water and the means for additional growth. The
increased availability of water in the area allowed Las Vegas to become a
[water stop](/wiki/Water_stop "Water stop"), first for [wagon
trains](/wiki/Wagon_train "Wagon train") and later [railroads](/wiki/Railroad
"Railroad"), on the trail between [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles,_California
"Los Angeles, California"), [California](/wiki/California "California"), and
points east such as [Albuquerque](/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico "Albuquerque,
New Mexico"), [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico").

The [San Pedro, Los Angeles & Salt
Lake](/wiki/Los_Angeles_and_Salt_Lake_Railroad "Los Angeles and Salt Lake
Railroad") Railroad was completed in 1905, linking Salt Lake City to [southern
California](/wiki/Southern_California "Southern California"). U.S. Senator
[William Andrews Clark](/wiki/William_Andrews_Clark "William Andrews Clark")
was the majority owner of the railroad, which was a corporation based in Utah.
Among its original incorporators were Utah's U.S. Senator [Thomas
Kearns](/wiki/Thomas_Kearns "Thomas Kearns") and his business partner David
Keith. Kearns, one of the richest and most powerful men in Utah, and Keith
were the owners of Utah's Silver King Coalition Mine, several mines in Nevada
and _[The Salt Lake Tribune](/wiki/The_Salt_Lake_Tribune "The Salt Lake
Tribune")_ newspaper. Kearns and Keith helped Clark ensure the success of the
new railroad across Utah and into Nevada to California. Curiously, for a time
there were two towns named Las Vegas. The east-side of Las Vegas (which
encompassed the modern Main Street and [Las Vegas
Boulevard](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Boulevard "Las Vegas Boulevard")) was owned by
Clark, and the west-side Las Vegas (which encompassed the area north of
modern-day [Bonanza Road](/wiki/Bonanza_Road "Bonanza Road")) was owned by
J.T. McWilliams, who was hired by the Stewart family during the sale of the
Las Vegas Rancho and bought available land west of the ranch. It was from
their property that Las Vegas took form.

Clark subsequently built another railroad branching off from Las Vegas to the
boomtown of [Bullfrog](/wiki/Bullfrog,_Nevada "Bullfrog, Nevada") called the
[Las Vegas and Tonopah Railroad](/wiki/Las_Vegas_and_Tonopah_Railroad "Las
Vegas and Tonopah Railroad"). With the revenue coming down both railways that
intersected there, the area of Las Vegas was quickly growing. On May 15, 1905,
Las Vegas officially was founded as a city, when 110 acres (45 ha), in what
would later become downtown, were auctioned to ready buyers. Las Vegas was the
driving force in the creation of [Clark County](/wiki/Clark_County,_Nevada
"Clark County, Nevada"), [Nevada](/wiki/Nevada "Nevada") in 1909 and the city
was incorporated in 1911 as a part of the county. The first mayor of Las Vegas
was [Peter Buol](/wiki/Peter_Buol "Peter Buol") who served from 1911-1913.

Shortly after the city's incorporation, the State of Nevada reluctantly became
the last western state to outlaw gaming. This occurred at midnight, October 1,
1910, when a strict anti-gambling law became effective in Nevada. It even
forbade the western custom of flipping a coin for the price of a drink.
Nonetheless, Las Vegas had a diversified economy and a stable and prosperous
business community, and therefore continued to grow until 1917. In that year,
a combination of economic influences and the redirection of resources by the
federal government in support of the war effort forced the [Las Vegas and
Tonopah Railroad](/wiki/Las_Vegas_and_Tonopah_Railroad "Las Vegas and Tonopah
Railroad") to declare bankruptcy. Although William Clark sold the remains of
the company to the [Union Pacific Railroad](/wiki/Union_Pacific_Railroad
"Union Pacific Railroad"), a nationwide strike in 1922 left Las Vegas in a
desperate state.

## 1930–1941: Hoover Dam and the first
casinos[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 1930–1941: Hoover Dam and the first casinos")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Adams_Boulder_Dam_1942.jpg/220px-
Adams_Boulder_Dam_1942.jpg)](/wiki/File:Adams_Boulder_Dam_1942.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Adams_Boulder_Dam_1942.jpg "Enlarge")

Hoover Dam in 1942

On July 3, 1930, President [Herbert Hoover](/wiki/Herbert_Hoover "Herbert
Hoover") signed the appropriation bill for the [Boulder Dam](/wiki/Hoover_Dam
"Hoover Dam"). The dam was later renamed the Hoover Dam during the Truman
administration. Work started on the dam in 1931 and Las Vegas' population
swelled from around 5,000 citizens to 25,000, with most of the newcomers
looking for a job building the dam. However, the demographic of the work force
consisting of males from across the country with no attachment to the area
created a market for large scale entertainment. A combination of local Las
Vegas business owners, and Mafia crime lords helped develop the casinos and
[showgirl](/wiki/Showgirl "Showgirl") theaters to entertain the largely male
dam construction workers.[11]

Despite the influx of known crime figures, the local business community tried
to cast Las Vegas in a respectable light when the [Secretary of the
Interior](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Interior "United States
Secretary of the Interior") [Ray Lyman Wilbur](/wiki/Ray_Lyman_Wilbur "Ray
Lyman Wilbur") visited in 1929 to inspect the dam site. However a subordinate
was found with [alcohol](/wiki/Alcoholic_beverage "Alcoholic beverage") on his
breath (this was during the time of [Prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition
"Prohibition")) after a visit to [Block
16](/w/index.php?title=Block_16&action=edit&redlink=1 "Block 16 \(page does
not exist\)") in Las Vegas. The government ultimately decided that a federal-
controlled town, [Boulder City](/wiki/Boulder_City,_Nevada "Boulder City,
Nevada"), would be erected for the dam workers.

Realizing that gambling would be profitable for local business, the Nevada
state legislature legalized gambling at the local level in 1931. Las Vegas,
with a small but already well-established illegal gambling industry, was
poised to begin its rise as the gaming capital of the world. The county issued
the first gambling license in 1931 to the [Northern
Club](/wiki/Northern_Club_\(casino\) "Northern Club \(casino\)"), and soon
other casinos were licensed on [Fremont Street](/wiki/Fremont_Street "Fremont
Street") like the [Las Vegas Club](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Club "Las Vegas Club") and
the [Apache Hotel](/w/index.php?title=Apache_Hotel&action=edit&redlink=1
"Apache Hotel \(page does not exist\)"). Fremont Street became the first paved
street in Las Vegas[12] and received the city's first traffic light in 1931.

In reply, the federal government restricted movement of the dam workers to Las
Vegas. Smuggling and circuitous routes then were developed. In 1934, to
curtail these activities and the resulting growth of criminal figures in the
gambling industry, the city's leading figures purged gambling dens and started
an effort to stem the flow of workers from the dam. This only emboldened some
dam workers who still contrived to visit Las Vegas. A celebration of this era
has become known as [Helldorado Days](/wiki/Helldorado_Days_\(Las_Vegas\)
"Helldorado Days \(Las Vegas\)").[13]

Although the suppression efforts resulted in declines at gambling venues and
resulted in a business downturn, the city was recharged — both literally and
figuratively — when the dam was completed in 1935. In 1937, [Southern Nevada
Power](/wiki/Nevada_Power "Nevada Power") became the first utility to supply
power from the dam, and Las Vegas was its first customer. Electricity flowed
into Las Vegas and Fremont Street became known as [Glitter
Gulch](/wiki/Fremont_Street_Experience "Fremont Street Experience") due to the
many bright lights powered by electricity from Hoover Dam. Meanwhile, although
the dam worker population disappeared, Hoover Dam and its reservoir, [Lake
Mead](/wiki/Lake_Mead "Lake Mead"), turned into tourist attractions on their
own and the need for additional higher class hotels became clear.

In 1940, [U.S. Route 95](/wiki/U.S._Route_95_\(Nevada\) "U.S. Route 95
\(Nevada\)") was finally extended south into Las Vegas, giving the city two
major access roads. Also in 1940 Las Vegas's first permanent [radio
station](/wiki/Radio_station "Radio station"), [KENO](/wiki/KENO "KENO"),
began broadcasting replacing the niche occupied earlier by transient
broadcasters.

## 1941–1945 war
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 1941–1945 war years")]

Main article: [Las Vegas in the 1940s](/wiki/Las_Vegas_in_the_1940s "Las Vegas
in the 1940s")

On January 25, 1941 the [U.S. Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States
Army") established a flexible [gunnery
school](/w/index.php?title=Gunnery_school&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gunnery
school \(page does not exist\)") for the [United States Army Air
Corps](/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Corps "United States Army Air Corps") in
Las Vegas. Mayor [John L.
Russell](/w/index.php?title=John_L._Russell_\(mayor\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"John L. Russell \(mayor\) \(page does not exist\)") signed over land to the
U.S. Army [Quartermaster Corps](/wiki/Quartermaster_Corps "Quartermaster
Corps") for this development. The gunnery school later would become [Nellis
Air Force Base](/wiki/Nellis_Air_Force_Base "Nellis Air Force Base"). The U.S
Army was not pleased with the legal [prostitution](/wiki/Prostitution
"Prostitution") in Las Vegas and in 1942 forced Las Vegas to outlaw the
practice, putting Block 16, the local [red light
district](/wiki/Red_light_district "Red light district") permanently out of
business.

On April 3, 1941, hotel owner Thomas Hull opened the [El Rancho
Vegas](/wiki/El_Rancho_Vegas "El Rancho Vegas"). It was the first resort on
what would become the [Las Vegas Strip](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip "Las Vegas
Strip"). The hotel gained much of its fame from the gourmet
[buffet](/wiki/Buffet "Buffet") that it offered.

On October 30, 1942, [R. E.
Griffith](/w/index.php?title=R._E._Griffith&action=edit&redlink=1 "R. E.
Griffith \(page does not exist\)") rebuilt on the site of a nightclub called
[Pair-O-Dice](/wiki/Pair-O-Dice "Pair-O-Dice"),[14] that first opened in 1930,
and renamed it [Hotel Last Frontier](/wiki/Hotel_Last_Frontier "Hotel Last
Frontier"). A few more resorts were built on and around Fremont Street but the
next hotel on the Strip publicly demonstrated the influence of [organized
crime](/wiki/Organized_crime "Organized crime") on Las Vegas. Although ethnic
organized crime figures had been involved in some of the operations at the
hotels, the Mafia bosses never owned or controlled the hotels and clubs which
remained monopolized by hard-bitten local Las Vegas families who were
unwilling to cede ground to the crime bosses and proved strong enough to push
back. This changed in post-war Las Vegas when Jewish gangster [Bugsy
Siegel](/wiki/Bugsy_Siegel "Bugsy Siegel"), with help from friend and fellow
mob boss [Meyer Lansky](/wiki/Meyer_Lansky "Meyer Lansky"), poured money
through Mormon-owned banks for cover of legitimacy and built [The
Flamingo](/wiki/Flamingo_Las_Vegas "Flamingo Las Vegas") in 1946.

## 1946–1955: postwar
boom[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 1946–1955: postwar boom")]

Main articles: [Las Vegas in the 1940s](/wiki/Las_Vegas_in_the_1940s "Las
Vegas in the 1940s") and [Las Vegas in the 1950s](/wiki/Las_Vegas_in_the_1950s
"Las Vegas in the 1950s")

The Flamingo initially lost money and [Siegel](/wiki/Bugsy_Siegel "Bugsy
Siegel") died in a hail of gunfire in Beverly Hills, California in the summer
of 1947. Additionally, local police and Clark County Sheriff deputies were
notorious for their heavy-handed tactics toward mobsters who "grew too big for
their pants." However, many mobsters saw the potential that gambling offered
in Las Vegas. From 1952 to 1957, through money and institutional lending
provided by the [Teamsters Union](/wiki/Teamsters_Union "Teamsters Union") and
some Mormon bankers they built the [Sahara](/wiki/Sahara_Hotel_and_Casino
"Sahara Hotel and Casino"), the [Sands](/wiki/Sands_Hotel "Sands Hotel"), the
[New Frontier](/wiki/New_Frontier_Hotel_and_Casino "New Frontier Hotel and
Casino"), the [Royal
Nevada](/w/index.php?title=Royal_Nevada&action=edit&redlink=1 "Royal Nevada
\(page does not exist\)"), the [Showboat](/wiki/Showboat_Hotel_and_Casino
"Showboat Hotel and Casino"), [The Riviera](/wiki/Riviera_\(hotel_and_casino\)
"Riviera \(hotel and casino\)"), [The Fremont](/wiki/Fremont_Hotel_and_Casino
"Fremont Hotel and Casino"), [Binion's Horseshoe](/wiki/Binion%27s_Horseshoe
"Binion's Horseshoe") (which was the [Apache
Hotel](/w/index.php?title=Apache_Hotel&action=edit&redlink=1 "Apache Hotel
\(page does not exist\)")), and finally [The
Tropicana](/wiki/Tropicana_Resort_%26_Casino "Tropicana Resort &
Casino").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Owned and operated by a joint combination of Mormon elders who provided
political and business legitimacy and people involved with organized crime who
provided unreported income and street muscle, such as [Meyer
Lansky](/wiki/Meyer_Lansky "Meyer Lansky"), these crime hotels became regarded
as the epitome of gambling entertainment.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Even
with the general knowledge that some of the owners of these casino resorts had
dubious backgrounds, by 1954, over 8 million people were visiting Las Vegas
yearly pumping $200 million into casinos. Gambling was no longer the only
attraction; the biggest stars of films and music like [Frank
Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank Sinatra"), [Dean Martin](/wiki/Dean_Martin
"Dean Martin"), [Andy Williams](/wiki/Andy_Williams "Andy Williams"),
[Liberace](/wiki/Liberace "Liberace"), [Bing Crosby](/wiki/Bing_Crosby "Bing
Crosby"), [Carol Channing](/wiki/Carol_Channing "Carol Channing"), and others
performed in intimate settings. After coming to see these stars, the tourists
would resume gambling, and then eat at the gourmet buffets that have become a
staple of the casino industry.

However, the confluence of various marginal and/or suspected groups such as
[Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews"), [Sicilians](/wiki/Sicilian_American "Sicilian
American"), and [Mormons](/wiki/Mormons "Mormons") into the gambling
enterprises in Las Vegas and the subsequent cornering of the gambling market
in the city by these groups sparked a two-year investigation by Senator [Estes
Kefauver](/wiki/Estes_Kefauver "Estes Kefauver") and his [Senate Special
Committee to Investigate Crime in Interstate Commerce](/wiki/Kefauver_hearings
"Kefauver hearings") in 1950–51.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
hearing concluded that [organized crime](/wiki/Organized_crime "Organized
crime") money was incontrovertibly tied to the Las Vegas casinos and was
becoming the controlling interest in the city thereby earning for the groups
vast amounts of income which was strengthening their influence in the country.
This led to a proposal by the Senate to institute federal gambling control.
Only through the power and influence of Nevada's Senator [Pat
McCarran](/wiki/Pat_McCarran "Pat McCarran") did the proposal die in
committee.

Along with their connections in Hollywood and New York City, these interests
in Las Vegas were able to use publicity provided by these media capitals to
steer the rapid growth of tourism into Las Vegas thereby dooming [Galveston,
Texas](/wiki/Free_State_of_Galveston "Free State of Galveston"); [Hot Springs,
Arkansas](/wiki/Hot_Springs,_Arkansas "Hot Springs, Arkansas"); and other
illegal gaming centers around the nation.[15] Nevada's legal gaming as well as
the paradoxical increased scrutiny by local and federal law enforcement in
these other locales during the 1950s made their demise inevitable.

### Atomic
testing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Atomic testing")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Exercise_Desert_Rock_I_%28Buster-
Jangle_Dog%29_002.jpg/220px-Exercise_Desert_Rock_I_%28Buster-
Jangle_Dog%29_002.jpg)](/wiki/File:Exercise_Desert_Rock_I_\(Buster-
Jangle_Dog\)_002.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Exercise_Desert_Rock_I_\(Buster-Jangle_Dog\)_002.jpg "Enlarge")

Nuclear testing at the Nevada Test Site

While the Strip was booming, the [U.S. Atomic Energy
Commission](/wiki/United_States_Atomic_Energy_Commission "United States Atomic
Energy Commission") on January 27, 1951 [detonated](/wiki/Detonation
"Detonation") the first of over a hundred [atmospheric](/wiki/Atmospheric
"Atmospheric") [explosions](/wiki/Explosion "Explosion") at the [Nevada Test
Site](/wiki/Nevada_Test_Site "Nevada Test Site"). These atmospheric tests
would continue until enactment of the [Partial Test Ban
Treaty](/wiki/Partial_Test_Ban_Treaty "Partial Test Ban Treaty") in 1963 when
the tests moved underground. The last test explosion was in 1992. Despite the
dangers and risks, greatly underestimated at the time, of radiation exposure
from the fallout, Las Vegas advertised the explosions as another tourist
attraction and offered _[Atomic
Cocktails](/w/index.php?title=Atomic_Cocktails&action=edit&redlink=1 "Atomic
Cocktails \(page does not exist\)")_ in _Sky Rooms_ that offered a great view
of the [mushroom clouds](/wiki/Mushroom_cloud "Mushroom cloud").

The influx of government employees for the Atomic Energy Commission and from
the Mormon-controlled [Bank of Las
Vegas](/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bank of Las
Vegas \(page does not exist\)") spearheaded by [E. Parry
Thomas](/wiki/E._Parry_Thomas "E. Parry Thomas") during those years funded the
growing boom in casinos. But Las Vegas was doing more than growing casinos. In
1948, [McCarran Field](/wiki/McCarran_International_Airport "McCarran
International Airport") was established for commercial air traffic. In 1957
the [University of Nevada, Las Vegas](/wiki/University_of_Nevada,_Las_Vegas
"University of Nevada, Las Vegas") was first established, initially as a
branch of the [University of Nevada, Reno](/wiki/University_of_Nevada,_Reno
"University of Nevada, Reno") and becoming independent in 1969. In 1959 the
[Clark County Commission](/wiki/Clark_County,_Nevada#Clark_County_Commission
"Clark County, Nevada") built the [Las Vegas Convention
Center](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Convention_Center "Las Vegas Convention Center"),
which would become a vital part of the area's economy. A new utility company,
[Southwest Gas](/wiki/Southwest_Gas_Corporation "Southwest Gas Corporation")
expanded into Las Vegas in 1954.

## 1956–1969: the beginning of modern Las
Vegas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 1956–1969: the beginning of modern Las Vegas")]

Main article: [Las Vegas in the 1950s](/wiki/Las_Vegas_in_the_1950s "Las Vegas
in the 1950s")

### Howard
Hughes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Howard Hughes")]

In 1966, [Howard Hughes](/wiki/Howard_Hughes "Howard Hughes"), the eccentric
hero of the American aviation industry, and noted American entrepreneurial
financier with vast connections to long established networks in the country,
moved to Las Vegas. Initially staying in the [Desert Inn](/wiki/Desert_Inn
"Desert Inn"), he refused to vacate his room and instead decided to purchase
the entire hotel. Hughes extended his financial empire to include Las Vegas
real estate, hotels and media outlets, spending an estimated $300 million and
using his considerable powers to take over many of the well known hotels,
especially the organized crime connected venues and he quickly became one of
the most powerful men in Las Vegas. He was instrumental in changing the image
of Las Vegas from its Wild West roots into a more refined cosmopolitan city.

### Hank
Greenspun[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Hank Greenspun")]

The local newspaper _[Las Vegas Sun](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Sun "Las Vegas Sun")_ and
its editor [Hank Greenspun](/wiki/Hank_Greenspun "Hank Greenspun") led a
crusade in those days to expose all the criminal ties, activities, and
government corruption in Las Vegas. His [investigative
reporting](/wiki/Investigative_reporting "Investigative reporting") and
editorials led to the exposure of [Clark County](/wiki/Clark_County,_Nevada
"Clark County, Nevada") Sheriff [Glen Jones](/wiki/Glen_Jones "Glen Jones")'
ownership of a [brothel](/wiki/Brothel "Brothel") and the resignation of
[Lieutenant Governor](/wiki/Lieutenant_Governor_of_Nevada "Lieutenant Governor
of Nevada") [Clifford A. Jones](/wiki/Clifford_A._Jones "Clifford A. Jones")
as the state's national committeeman for the [Democratic
Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party \(United
States\)"). Before his death in 1989, Hank Greenspun founded [The Greenspun
Corporation](/wiki/The_Greenspun_Corporation "The Greenspun Corporation") to
manage his family's assets, and it remains a major influence in Las Vegas,
with media holdings in print, television and the Internet; substantial real
estate holdings; and ownership stakes in a number of casinos.

### Local
government[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Local government")]

One problem for the City of Las Vegas was that the Strip did not reside in Las
Vegas . Because of this, the city lost tax revenue. There was a push to annex
the Strip by the City of Las Vegas, but [The Syndicate](/wiki/Organized_crime
"Organized crime") used the Clark County Commissioners to pull a legal
maneuver by organizing the [Las Vegas Strip](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip "Las Vegas
Strip") properties into an unincorporated township called
[Paradise](/wiki/Paradise,_Nevada "Paradise, Nevada"). Under Nevada Law, an
incorporated town, Las Vegas, cannot annex an unincorporated township. To this
day, virtually all of the Strip remains outside the City of Las Vegas.

###
Desegregation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Desegregation")]

Much like in other American settled counties and towns throughout the United
States, entertainment venues were segregated between black- and white-owned
businesses. With almost all of the businesses owned and operated by whites,
[Black Americans](/wiki/Black_Americans "Black Americans") were barred from
entering the venues which remained focused, regardless of their legitimacy or
criminality, on entertaining a white-only clientele. As a result of property
deeds, businesses owned by or mainly serving non-whites were confined to clubs
on the "west side" of the tracks. This also was enforced in many of the work
positions. Thus, [African Americans](/wiki/African_Americans "African
Americans") (except those who provided the labor for low-paying menial
positions or entertainment) and Hispanics were limited in employment
occupations at the white-owned clubs. However, because of employment deals
with black worker groups, many clubs favored black workers, and the
[Hispanic](/wiki/Hispanic "Hispanic") population actually decreased ninety
percent from 2,275 to just 236 by the mid-1950s.

Organized crime-owned businesses saw an opportunity in not dividing their
clientele by race and, despite property deeds and city and county codes
barring such activities, made several attempts at
[desegregating](/wiki/Desegregation "Desegregation") their businesses in the
hopes of putting out of operation the non-white owned clubs and expanding
their own market share. An attempt was made at forming an all-integrated
night-club modeled on the [Harlem](/wiki/Harlem "Harlem") Clubs of New York
City during the 1920s and 1930s, like those owned by German-Jewish gangster
[Dutch Schultz](/wiki/Dutch_Schultz "Dutch Schultz"). On May 24, 1955, Jewish
crime boss Will Max Schwartz, along with other investors, opened the [Moulin
Rouge](/wiki/Moulin_Rouge_Las_Vegas "Moulin Rouge Las Vegas"). It was a very
upscale and racially integrated casino that actually competed against the
resorts on the Strip, especially the non-white owned strips on the west side.
By the end of the year, the casino closed as Schwartz and his partners had a
falling out, but the seeds for racial integration were sown.

Many sources have credited [Frank Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank
Sinatra") and the [Rat Pack](/wiki/Rat_Pack "Rat Pack") as a significant
driving force behind desegregation in the casinos.[16] One famous story tells
of Sinatra's refusal to perform at the Sands Hotel unless the hotel provided
[Sammy Davis Jr.](/wiki/Sammy_Davis_Jr. "Sammy Davis Jr.") with a room.[17]
The famed performing group made similar demands at other venues, forcing
owners to amend their policies over time.[18]

However, it took political action, most often supported by Jewish crime
groups, for racial desegregation to occur. In 1960, the NAACP threatened a
protest of the city's casinos for their policies. A meeting between the NAACP,
the mayor and local businessmen resulted in citywide casino desegregation,
starting with the employees. Many whites were attritioned from positions and
their jobs given to the black unions. Along with the rest of the country, Las
Vegas experienced the [struggle for civil rights](/wiki/Civil_rights_movement
"Civil rights movement"). Activists like [James B.
McMillan](/wiki/James_B._McMillan "James B. McMillan"), [Grant
Sawyer](/wiki/Grant_Sawyer "Grant Sawyer"), Bob Bailey, and [Charles
Keller](/wiki/Charles_Keller "Charles Keller") dragged Las Vegas to racial
integration.

Aside from seeing no business advantage to excluding non-white customers from
casinos and clubs, the organized crime groups themselves were composed of
people of ethnicities (Jewish and Italian) that faced discrimination from
[WASP](/wiki/White_Anglo-Saxon_Protestant "White Anglo-Saxon Protestant")
America and thus could understand the plight of blacks. This was also a
driving force behind the integration advocated by ethnic performers such as
Sinatra and Martin.

Another big force for equality was Mayor [Oran Gragson](/wiki/Oran_Gragson
"Oran Gragson"). Spurred into local politics by a vigilante ring of cops who
repeatedly broke into his appliance store, he implemented infrastructure
improvements for the minority neighborhoods in Las Vegas, backed the NAACP in
its actions, and promoted black workers for jobs. He also championed the cause
of the [Paiute
tribe](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Tribe_of_Paiute_Indians_of_the_Las_Vegas_Indian_Colony
"Las Vegas Tribe of Paiute Indians of the Las Vegas Indian Colony") that owned
a small portion of Las Vegas. Gragson stopped the U.S. government from
evicting the tribe and actually made infrastructure improvements for them. His
work helped reverse the decrease of minority populations in Las Vegas.

Local legislation kept up with the national legislation and integration was
finally established. The only real violence came as a result of school
integration, with violent riots and fights occurring in [Clark High
School](/wiki/Ed_W._Clark_High_School "Ed W. Clark High School") when black
gangs and youths began attacking the whites. Integration sparked [white
flight](/wiki/White_flight "White flight") from the school district from 1965
to 1971.that school was then later destroyed.

## 1970-1988: Explosive
growth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: 1970-1988: Explosive growth")]

On a percentage basis, Las Vegas and Clark County experienced incredibly high
growth rates starting in the 1930s and lasting until the [late 2000s
recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"). During that period, the
population of the city more than doubled in most decades. The rate slowed down
in the 1970s with the decrease of the white birth rate, but never dropped
below 60% (1980–1990), and even accelerated after 1990 due to immigration. By
2000, Las Vegas was the largest city founded in the 20th century,[19] and by
2006 it was the 28th largest city in the US, with a population of 552,000 in
the city and nearly 1.8 million in Clark County. The explosive growth resulted
in rapid development of commercial and residential areas throughout the Las
Vegas Valley. The strong boom in the resort business led to many new
condominium developments all along the Strip and downtown area. Also [urban
sprawl](/wiki/Urban_sprawl "Urban sprawl") development of single-family homes
continued across the valley, building the areas of Henderson, [North Las
Vegas](/wiki/North_Las_Vegas "North Las Vegas"), Centennial Hills, and
[Summerlin](/wiki/Summerlin "Summerlin"). The rapid development and population
growth both halted abruptly in the late 2000s recession.[20][21]

During this period of time, American author and journalist [Hunter S.
Thompson](/wiki/Hunter_S._Thompson "Hunter S. Thompson") wrote and published
his seminal novel, _[Fear and Loathing in Las
Vegas](/wiki/Fear_and_Loathing_in_Las_Vegas_\(novel\) "Fear and Loathing in
Las Vegas \(novel\)")_ , detailing the experience of his 1971 trip to the
city.

On November 21, 1980 the [MGM Grand Hotel and
Casino](/wiki/MGM_Grand_Hotel_and_Casino "MGM Grand Hotel and Casino"),
suffered a [devastating fire](/wiki/MGM_Grand_fire "MGM Grand fire"). A total
of 85 people died and 785 were injured in what remains the worst disaster in
Nevada history. The property was eventually sold and reopened as [Bally's Las
Vegas](/wiki/Bally%27s_Las_Vegas "Bally's Las Vegas"), while MGM moved south
to [Tropicana Avenue](/wiki/Tropicana_Avenue "Tropicana Avenue").

## Since 1989: the megaresort
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Since 1989: the megaresort era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Las_Vegas_89.jpg/300px-
Las_Vegas_89.jpg)](/wiki/File:Las_Vegas_89.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Las_Vegas_89.jpg "Enlarge")

The Strip resorts in late 2009

The "Mafia/Rat Pack" Las Vegas of the mid-20th century came to a gradual end
in the 1980s with the aging out of the World War II generation, the decline of
organized crime elements, and the rise of baby boomer entrepreneurs who began
a new chapter in the city's history, the so-called
[megaresort](/wiki/Megaresort "Megaresort") era. Las Vegas began to become a
more commercialized, family-oriented place with large corporations coming to
own the hotels, casinos, and nightclubs in place of Mafia bosses. The
[megaresort](/wiki/Megaresort "Megaresort") era kicked off in 1989 with the
construction of [The Mirage](/wiki/The_Mirage "The Mirage"). Built by
developer [Steve Wynn](/wiki/Steve_Wynn "Steve Wynn"), it was the first resort
built with money from [Wall Street](/wiki/Wall_Street "Wall Street"), selling
$630 million in [junk bonds](/wiki/Junk_bonds "Junk bonds"). Its 3,044 rooms,
each with gold tinted windows, set a new standard for Vegas luxury and
attracted tourists in droves, leading to additional financing and rapid growth
on the [Las Vegas Strip](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip "Las Vegas Strip"). Numerous
landmark hotels and other structures were razed to make way for ever-larger
and more opulent resorts including:

  * 1990: [Rio](/wiki/Rio_All_Suite_Hotel_and_Casino "Rio All Suite Hotel and Casino") and [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur_Hotel_and_Casino "Excalibur Hotel and Casino")
  * 1993: [MGM Grand](/wiki/MGM_Grand_Las_Vegas "MGM Grand Las Vegas"), [Treasure Island](/wiki/Treasure_Island_Hotel_and_Casino "Treasure Island Hotel and Casino"), and [Luxor](/wiki/Luxor_Las_Vegas "Luxor Las Vegas"),
  * 1996: [Stratosphere Tower](/wiki/Stratosphere_Tower "Stratosphere Tower") and [Monte Carlo](/wiki/Monte_Carlo_Resort_and_Casino "Monte Carlo Resort and Casino")
  * 1997: [New York-New York](/wiki/New_York-New_York_Hotel_%26_Casino "New York-New York Hotel & Casino")
  * 1998: [Bellagio](/wiki/Bellagio_\(hotel_and_casino\) "Bellagio \(hotel and casino\)")
  * 1999: [Mandalay Bay](/wiki/Mandalay_Bay_Resort_and_Casino "Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino"), [Venetian](/wiki/The_Venetian,_Las_Vegas "The Venetian, Las Vegas"), and [Paris](/wiki/Paris_Las_Vegas "Paris Las Vegas")
  * 2000: [Planet Hollywood](/wiki/Planet_Hollywood_Resort_and_Casino "Planet Hollywood Resort and Casino") (Formerly Aladdin)
  * 2001: [Palms](/wiki/Palms_Hotel_and_Casino "Palms Hotel and Casino")
  * 2005: [Wynn](/wiki/Wynn_Las_Vegas "Wynn Las Vegas") (opened in April by [Wynn Resorts Limited](/wiki/Wynn_Resorts_Limited "Wynn Resorts Limited") opened its new flagship, the constructed at a cost of US$2.7 billion.)
  * 2007: [Palazzo](/wiki/The_Palazzo "The Palazzo")
  * 2008: [Encore](/wiki/Encore_Suites "Encore Suites")
  * 2009: [CityCenter](/wiki/CityCenter "CityCenter")
  * 2010: [The Cosmopolitan](/wiki/Cosmopolitan_of_Las_Vegas "Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas")

[Helldorado Days](/wiki/Helldorado_Days_\(Las_Vegas\) "Helldorado Days \(Las
Vegas\)") was resumed in 2005 for the City of Las Vegas'
[centennial](/wiki/Centennial "Centennial") celebration.[13]

### Downturn and
recovery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Las_Vegas&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Downturn and recovery")]

Despite the success, the home [mortgage crisis](/wiki/Mortgage_crisis
"Mortgage crisis") and the late 2000s recession affected the economic success.
Soon after, new home construction was stalled, and construction projects were
either canceled, postponed, or continued with financial troubles. Some of
these projects included the [MGM Mirage](/wiki/MGM_Mirage "MGM Mirage")
property of [CityCenter](/wiki/CityCenter "CityCenter"),
[Fontainebleau](/wiki/Fontainebleau_Resort_Las_Vegas "Fontainebleau Resort Las
Vegas"), [Echelon](/wiki/Echelon_Place "Echelon Place"), and [The
Plaza](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Plaza "Las Vegas Plaza"). The global financial
situation also had a negative effect on gaming and tourism revenue, causing
many of the companies to report net loss. However starting in 2013, the sector
began to turn around with the proposal of the Resorts World projects replacing
the Echelon currently under construction. The Alon resort is planned to resume
the site formerly the Frontier and originally planned for the Plaza.
Fontainbleau is currently being on the process of being sold and resumed. Wynn
Resorts is also planning an additional tower with a central lake planned for
2020 and a new stadium opened near the New York New York hotel on 2016.

Las Vegas has still managed to host many conventions and major events, such as
the annual [Latin Grammy Awards](/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Awards "Latin Grammy
Awards"), & the [Consumer Electronics Show](/wiki/Consumer_Electronics_Show
"Consumer Electronics Show").

Many analysts agree that the Las Vegas economy is recovering, with improving
conditions in tourism and the housing market for 2013.[22][23] Prices are
rising and there has been a large increase in the million dollar home market,
with many new custom homes being built. January 2013 marks the 19th
consecutive month with home sales higher than the same month in the previous
year.[24] In addition, Las Vegas was named America's Top Turn Around Market
for 2012 by [Trulia](/wiki/Trulia "Trulia").[25]

In June 2017, a [heat wave](/wiki/2017_North_American_heat_wave "2017 North
American heat wave") grounded more than 40 airline flights of small aircraft
were grounded, with [American Airlines](/wiki/American_Airlines "American
Airlines") reducing sales on certain flights to prevent the vehicles from
being over the maximum weight permitted for safe takeoff and [Las
Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las Vegas") tying its record high at 117 [degrees
Fahrenheit](/wiki/Degrees_Fahrenheit "Degrees Fahrenheit").[26]

During the late evening of October 1, 2017, Las Vegas became the scene of the
deadliest [mass shooting](/wiki/2017_Las_Vegas_Strip_shooting "2017 Las Vegas
Strip shooting") in the history of the United States, when a gunman opened
fire on country-music festival goers, killing 59 and injuring more than
500.[27]
